intro: Plagiobothrys chorisianus var. chorisianus, commonly known as the Chorisian bluecurls, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in open habitats such as grasslands and coastal bluffs. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
